column2: Republican Party groups: sources	"

column1: By Joseph Menn
column2: Mark Hosenball and John Walcott

column1: Hackers targeted the computer systems of presidential candidate Donald Trump and Republican Party organizations as well as Democratic Party networks
column2: sources familiar with investigations into the attacks said.At least one Trump staff member's email account was infected with malware in 2015 and sent malicious emails to colleagues
column3: according to one insider for the Republican candidate's campaign and an outside security expert. It was unclear whether or not the hackers actually gained access to campaign computers.In the past month
column4: U.S. security officials have said that starting last year
column5: hackers infiltrated computers of the Democratic National Committee (DNC)
column6: the presidential campaign of Hillary Clinton and her party's congressional fundraising committee.

column1: U.S. officials said they have concluded that Russia or its proxies were responsible
column2: leading to calls by some Democrats and cyber security officials for the Obama administration to blame Russia publicly. Kremlin officials have dismissed the allegations as absurd
column3: but there is anxiety in Washington over the possibility that a foreign power might be using hacked information to meddle in the Nov. 8 U.S. election.The Trump campaign has hired security firm CrowdStrike
column4: which also is assisting the Democratic National Committee
column5: according to one person briefed on the matter. The company declined to comment.A different outside security firm was hired to examine software the Trump and Clinton campaigns use to manage mailings
column6: electronic outreach and other campaign efforts
column7: another person who was briefed on the issue said.A spokeswoman for Trump's campaign declined to comment. A spokesman for the Republican National Committee could not immediately be reached for comment.

column1: The tools and techniques used to hack Republican targets resemble those employed in attacks on Democratic Party organizations
column2: including the DNC and Clinton's campaign organization
column3: two sources said. That has led U.S. officials to reach a preliminary assessment that Russia's military and civilian intelligence agencies or their proxies have targeted both political parties.Attempts to hack into Republican political organizations over an extended period were reported in intelligence bulletins circulated by U.S. agencies
column4: four sources said. They did not disclose the identities of the organizations.

column1: Two U.S. security officials said the FBI and the Department of Homeland Security have offered assistance to both political parties in identifying possible intrusions and upgrading their defenses against what one of the officials called ""constantly evolving threats."" (Reporting by Joseph Menn in San Francisco
column2: Mark Hosenball and John Walcott in Washington; Editing by Grant McCool)"	['Clinton'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-statedepartment-video-idUSKCN10T2IJ	U.S. State Department finds briefing video cut but unclear why	"
WASHINGTON A U.S. State Department video of a press briefing about secret U.S.-Iran nuclear talks was deliberately edited but there is no evidence to suggest the cut was intended to hide information
column2: a U.S. spokesman said on Thursday after further details were released of an investigation into the incident.""We are confident the video of that press briefing was deliberately edited
column3: State Department spokesman John Kirby told reporters
column4: adding: ""What we were not able to determine is why the edit was made in the first place. There's no evidence to suggest it was made with the intent to conceal information from the public.""The excised portion of a Dec. 2
column6: briefing included a question about whether an earlier spokeswoman for the department had misled reporters about whether the United States was holding secret direct nuclear talks with Iran.

column1: The State Department initially said it was caused by a ""glitch"" but later said it was a deliberate omission.Kirby said the investigation by the department's Office of the Legal Adviser could not rule out that a technical glitch might have deleted the portion of the video because of the ""choppy nature of the cut.""
He said the findings had now been shared with Secretary of State John Kerry and with congressional members.
(Reporting by Lesley Wroughton; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	[]	[]
2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-iran-payment-idUSKCN10T2E9	U.S. says payment to Iran used as leverage for prisoners' release	"

WASHINGTON The U.S. State Department said on Thursday it released $400 million in cash to Iran under a tribunal settlement only once it was assured that American prisoners had been freed and had boarded a plane.""The payment of the $400 million was not done until after the prisoners were released
column2: State Department spokesman John Kirby told reporters.""We took advantage of that to make sure we had the maximum leverage possible to get our people out and get them out safely
column3: Kirby added.It was the first time the administration has said publicly that it used the payment as leverage to ensure the prisoners were released by Iran.Three of the five prisoners
column4: including Jason Rezaian
column5: the Washington Posts's Tehran bureau chief; Saeed Abedini
column6: a pastor from Idaho and Amir Hekmati
column7: a former U.S. Marine from Flint
column9: as well as some family members
column10: were part of a prisoner exchange that followed the lifting of most international sanctions against Iran following a nuclear deal in 2015.

column1: One more prisoner
column2: Nosratollah Khosravi-Roodsari
column3: chose to remain in Iran
column4: while a fifth prisoner
column5: American student Matthew Trevithick
column6: was released separately.   Both U.S. President Barack Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry have denied that the payment was ransom for the release of the prisoners or tied to the Iran nuclear deal.The White House announced on Jan. 17 it was releasing $400 million in funds frozen since 1981
column7: plus $1.3 billion in interest owed to Iran
column8: as part of a settlement of a long-standing Iranian claim at the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal in The Hague.

column1: The funds were part of a trust fund Iran used before its 1979 Islamic Revolution to buy U.S. military equipment that was tied up for decades in litigation at the tribunal.The payment was made by the United States in cash due to international sanctions against Iran.
The administration has maintained that negotiations over the funds and the prisoners were conducted on separate tracks and were in no way linked.Representative Jason Chaffetz
column2: chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
column3: has asked Kerry to appear at a future committee hearing to discuss the payment. (Reporting by Lesley Wroughton; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Obama']	[]

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-pennsylvania-kane-idUSKCN10T1YF	Pennsylvania governor nominates replacement for convicted attorney general	"
By Joseph Ax
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf on Thursday nominated the state's inspector general to serve as interim attorney general until November's election
column2: temporarily replacing Kathleen Kane
column3: who resigned the post earlier this week after her conviction for perjury.Bruce Beemer
column4: who previously served under Kane as first deputy in the attorney general's office
column5: will have to be confirmed by the state Senate.Wolf said in a statement that he had already conferred with both Republican and Democratic leaders in the Senate and expected a quick confirmation. Beemer would hold the job until a successor is elected in November for a four-year term
column6: and then return to his role as inspector general.Kane announced her resignation on Tuesday
column7: a day after a jury convicted her of leaking sealed grand jury material to a news reporter in an effort to embarrass a political rival.The move will likely end a brief stint as acting attorney general for Bruce Castor
column8: whom Kane had hired as her second-in-command earlier this year.

column1: In a statement
column2: Castor said the governor was fulfilling his duties under the law.""I will do all within my power to see that the office of attorney general is in the best possible shape for whenever the next attorney general arrives
column3: Castor said.Castor
column4: the former Montgomery County district attorney
column5: made headlines earlier this year when he testified at a hearing for comedian Bill Cosby in his sexual assault case.

column1: Castor said he had agreed not to prosecute Cosby if the entertainer testified in a civil case brought by his accuser. But a court ruled Castor's claims were not enough to prevent the current district attorney from bringing charges.Kane's conviction
column2: meanwhile
column3: ended what had once been seen as a promising political career.Prosecutors said Kane believed former state prosecutor Frank Fina was behind a 2014 newspaper article that said she had abandoned a corruption investigation into Philadelphia officials.

column1: In an effort to take revenge
column2: prosecutors said
column3: Kane leaked sealed details about a separate investigation that Fina declined to pursue and then lied about having done so to a grand jury investigating the matter.Kane had portrayed the charges as politically motivated
column4: after she revealed lewd emails exchanged among judges
column5: state officials and prosecutors that she discovered while re-examining the Jerry Sandusky molestation investigation.Several officials
column6: including two state Supreme Court justices
column7: lost their jobs in the wake of the email scandal

column2: Dustin Volz and John Walcott

column1: | WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Bill and Hillary Clinton's charitable foundation hired the security firm FireEye to examine its data systems after seeing indications they might have been hacked
column2: according to two sources familiar with the matter.So far
column3: no message or document hacked from the New York-based Clinton Foundation has surfaced in public
column4: the sources said.One of the sources and two U.S. security officials said that like hackers who targeted the Democratic National Committee
column5: Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign and the Democrats' congressional fundraising committee
column6: the hackers appear to have used ""spear phishing"" techniques to gain access to the foundation's network.ELSEWHERE IN THE NEWSU.S. swimmers trying to return from Rio yanked off flightA desperate country crushes 2
column8: plans bullet registryThese techniques include creating bogus emails or websites in an effort to gain access to Clinton Foundation staffers' emails and then to the foundation itself.

column1: Speaking on the condition of anonymity
column2: the U.S. officials said the hackers used the same techniques Russian intelligence agencies or their proxies employed against the Democratic Party groups
column3: which suggests that Russians also attacked the foundation.Kremlin officials dismissed as absurd the allegations of Moscow's involvement
column4: which were made last month amid political party nominating conventions for the Nov. 8 election.Neither former White House Counsel Kathryn Ruemmler
column5: the Clinton Foundation's principal lawyer
column6: nor a spokeswoman for the foundation responded to requests for comment on the hacking and the precautions the organization has taken.Officials with FireEye said the company could not discuss its clients.

column1: Although no documents have emerged
column2: the attacks have left some Democrats and Clinton campaign officials worried that the hackers might have obtained emails and voice messages that could be used to reinforce Republican charges that donors to the Clinton Foundation were rewarded with access to Clinton and her aides while she was secretary of state or to her husband
column3: former President Bill Clinton.Another concern: hackers or outlets such as the anti-secrecy WikiLeaks website could release documents and emails damaging to her presidential campaign
column4: several people familiar with the foundation's activities said.The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee convened a closed-door meeting on Wednesday to discuss best cyber security practices.The meeting
column5: according to people familiar with it
column6: included a recommendation that staff and lawmakers change their phone numbers and email addresses if that information was published online by hackers believed to be working for or with Russian intelligence agencies.

column1: One of the U.S. officials said
column2: however
column3: that the spear phishing pattern used against several organizations
column4: appears to reinforce the intelligence community's ""preliminary assessment"" that the attacks were intended more for espionage than for trying to influence the U.S. presidential election.So far
column5: said a third U.S. official familiar with the attacks
column6: there is no evidence that the hackers were able to follow any of the hacked emails into the State Department's classified email systems.Anxiety in Washington over the possibility that a foreign power might be using hacked information to meddle in the U.S. election has prompted some Democrats and cyber security experts to urge the Obama administration to blame Russia publicly.Rep. Jim Himes
column7: a Democrat on the House of Representatives intelligence committee
column8: said the United States should carry ""a big stick"" in cyber security matters. ""The U.S. government needs to be very clear
column10: and hold these people accountable.""Current and former White House and intelligence officials said the Obama administration is unlikely to blame Russia publicly
column11: given the difficulty of attributing the attacks without revealing American sources and methods
column13: and a fear that doing so could risk aggravating cyber conflict. (Reporting by Mark Hosenball

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-campaign-idUSKCN10S0TY	Trump hires 'street fighter' in new shakeup of White House campaign	"
By Steve Holland and Emily Flitter
U.S. Republican Donald Trump overhauled his presidential campaign team on Wednesday for the second time in less than two months
column2: hiring the head of a conservative news website to bolster his combative image and try to reverse poor opinion poll numbers.Trump named Steve Bannon

column5: a new position. He also promoted senior adviser Kellyanne Conway to the post of campaign manager. The latest shake-up combines Bannon
column6: a conservative flamethrower
column9: data-driven analyst who might be able to broaden Trump's appeal to women and independent voters.    It offers Trump's team a chance to return to the ""let Trump be Trump"" style practiced by former campaign manager Corey Lewandowski that helped Trump
column10: who has never held elective office
column11: win the Republican presidential nomination for the Nov. 8 election.    Lewandowski
column12: ousted in the last campaign reorganization in June

A Trump campaign statement announcing the changes touted a Bloomberg Politics article that branded Bannon ""the most dangerous political operative in America."" Whether that style will work in the fight against Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton is unclear. Trump
column14: a New York real estate developer and former reality TV host
column15: has largely been unable to extend his reach beyond white middle-class voters who pack his rallies.Trump trails Clinton in national opinion polls and in many battleground states
column16: potentially facing a big defeat that could also cost Republicans congressional races.        Trump
column17: who relishes revving up crowds with off-the-cuff remarks
column18: drew criticism for comments insulting women
column19: Muslims and Mexican immigrants during the primary campaign for the Republican nomination. He has since faced a barrage of criticism from Republicans over his campaign style and his refusal to stick to a policy message. In particular
column20: he has been rebuked for his prolonged feud with the family of a Muslim U.S. Army captain who was killed in the Iraq war. On Wednesday afternoon

column22: a Trump adviser who attended the briefing at the New York field office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation
column23: said the officials who conducted the two-hour session were ""absolutely professional"" and that it was ""a great conversation.""

Bannon likes to push the limits of polite conversation and revels in taking the fight up a notch

column12: a theme that Trump has been touching on in his campaign speeches.""My guess is Bannon will be a bull in a china shop and Conway will be focused on messaging and paid media

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-documents-idUSKCN10S2G9	FBI documents viewed in secure areas of the U.S. Capitol	"

WASHINGTON FBI documents about the agency's investigation into Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while secretary of state were being reviewed on Wednesday in secure rooms of the U.S. Capitol.Lawmakers and select staff from some congressional committees could page through the material
column2: parts of which are redacted
column3: in large binders labeled ""secret"" that the Federal Bureau of Investigation turned over to Congress on Tuesday.Republican lawmakers requested the information last month after the FBI recommended no criminal charges against Clinton.""Last I heard
column4: my colleagues had their turn with the documents at 1:30 p.m.
column5: said a Senate Judiciary committee aide. ""There's only one set of documents for all the interested Senate committees
column6: as I understand it.""She said those viewing the material were allowed to take notes. But if notes were taken on the classified parts
column7: those notes had to be left in the secure area with the documents. Clinton has been dogged for more than a year by questions about her use of a private email account while she was the nation's top diplomat from 2009 to 2013.Republicans have repeatedly hammered Clinton over the issue
column8: helping to drive opinion poll results showing that many U.S. voters doubt her trustworthiness. She faces Republican nominee Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election.

column1: The FBI said on Tuesday it had provided ""relevant materials"" to congressional committees looking into the matter.""The material contains classified and other sensitive information and is being provided with the expectation it will not be disseminated or disclosed without FBI concurrence
column2: the agency said in a statement.Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley
column3: a Republican
column4: said in a statement on Tuesday an initial review of the material showed most of it was marked unclassified.

column1: Grassley
column2: who has called for unclassified parts of the documents to be made public
column3: wrote on Wednesday to the Senate Security Office
column4: which has custody of the documents
column5: asking them to provide his committee with an unclassified version.Clinton campaign spokesman Brian Fallon in a statement also called for the public release of the documents
column6: ""rather than allow Republicans to mischaracterize them through selective
column7: partisan leaks.""The documents on the Senate side of the Capitol are under the control of the Office of Senate Security
column8: Senate aides said. In the House of Representatives
column9: another set was being viewed in a ""Secure Compartmented Information Facility
column10: an aide with the House Oversight and Government Reform committee said.

column1: Our investigators with (security) clearances have gone down there and looked at the documents
column2: the Oversight committee aide said. It was unclear how many lawmakers had actually seen the material so far. Most members of Congress were not in town because of a congressional recess.The documents were made available to the Judiciary
column3: Homeland Security
column4: and Appropriations committees in the Senate
column5: and the Oversight

column7: aides said.  The Intelligence committees on both sides of the Capitol also have copies

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-agriculture-m-a-grassley-idUSKCN10S2DW	U.S. senator expresses concern about ag tech mergers	"
By Diane Bartz
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Two major mergers in agricultural technology and seeds could hurt competition in the industry and make it harder for smaller companies to compete
column2: Senator Charles Grassley
column3: chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee
column4: wrote in a letter on Wednesday sent to antitrust enforcers.Grassley
column5: a Republican from Iowa
column6: urged the Federal Trade Commission
column7: which is reviewing the purchase of Syngenta AG by the China National Chemical Corp [CNNCC.UL]
column9: which is looking at the merger of Dow Chemical Co and DuPont Co
column10: to coordinate on the two reviews.""It is important that these transactions not be reviewed in isolation
column11: wrote Grassley. ""I urge the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission to collaborate
column13: with input from the Department of Agriculture
column14: in their analysis of the agricultural biotechnology and seed industry and the impact of these proposed transactions.""

column1: Dow and DuPont said in December that they would combine in an all-stock merger with plans to then break into three separate businesses. In February
column2: China's state-owned ChemChina [CNNCC.UL] made a $43 billion bid for Swiss seeds and pesticides group Syngenta.The deals by some of farmers' biggest global suppliers concerned Grassley
column3: who represents a largely agricultural state.

column1: I am concerned that the convergence of these proposed transactions - as well as others currently being discussed - will have an enhanced adverse impact on competition in the industry and raise barriers to entry for smaller companies
column2: he wrote.""I also am concerned that further concentration in the industry will impact the price and choice of chemicals and seed for farmers
column3: which ultimately will impact choice and costs for consumers. Finally
column4: I am concerned that further consolidation will diminish critical research and development initiatives
column5: added Grassley.

column1: The letter was dated Tuesday and sent to FTC Chairwoman Edith Ramirez and Renata Hesse
column2: the acting head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division. (Reporting by Diane Bartz; Editing by David Gregorio)"	['Grassley']	[]

9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-manafort-idUSKCN10S1GQ	Trump campaign chairman helped pro-Russians in Ukraine move money to U.S. firms: AP	"
WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's campaign chairman
column2: Paul Manafort
column3: helped a Ukrainian political party with close ties to Russia secretly move at least $2.2 million to two major Washington lobbying firms
column4: the Associated Press reported on Wednesday.The AP
column5: citing sources with direct knowledge of the effort
column6: said the transfers were set up in ways to obscure the Ukrainian party's attempts to sway U.S. policies
column7: using a nonprofit organization to distance funds from Ukrainian politicians.U.S. law requires American lobbyists to register and report in detail any ties to foreign political parties or leaders to the U.S. Justice Department.The heads of both firms - Podesta Group Inc and Mercury LLC - told the AP they had concluded their work did not merit disclosure to the department
column8: according to the report.Representatives for Trump and Mercury did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Podesta Group Chief Executive Officer Kimberley Fritts said its lawyers worked with those at Mercury to determine that registering under the Foreign Agent Registration Act was unnecessary. It also obtained a statement from the nonprofit in question saying it was not directly or indirectly involved with a foreign entity
column9: she said in an emailed statement. The Podesta Group was founded in 1987 by Tony Podesta and his brother John
column10: who now is campaign chairman for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton. John Podesta has not been with the firm for several years
column11: but his brother is its chairman.

column1: The AP report comes less than three months before the Nov. 8 election and as polls show Trump slipping behind Clinton.Trump's campaign on Wednesday announced a staff shake-up replacing Manafort as campaign manager after just two months. He will remain chairman and chief strategist.The New York Times this week reported Manafort's name was found on secret ledgers showing cash payments designated to him of more than $12 million from a Ukrainian party with Russian ties. Manafort has denied any impropriety.

Ukrainian officials confirmed Manafort's name appeared on a ledger and that more than $12 million had been allocated as an expenditure but said the presence of his name did not mean he received the funds.Clinton's campaign has said Manafort's associations are a troubling sign of ties between Trump's campaign team and pro-Kremlin elements in Ukraine.According to the AP
column2: in 2012 Manafort and associate Rick Gates worked on behalf of Ukraine's then-president
column3: Viktor Yanukovych
column4: and helped steer the efforts of European Centre for a Modern Ukraine
column5: an advocacy group that once included members of Yanukovych's party.

column1: The group paid at least $2.2 million to the Washington firms to push positions favorable to the party from 2012 until 2014
column2: when Yanukovych was ousted and fled to Russia
column3: the AP said
column4: citing sources. That work included efforts to counter a potential congressional resolution pressuring Yanukovych to release a political rival from prison
column5: the AP reported.Gates
column6: who also works for the Trump campaign
column7: told the AP his actions were lawful. He said he and Manafort had introduced the advocacy group to the firms and sometimes consulted with the firms on Ukrainian politics
column8: the report said.Podesta's Fritts said her firm was unaware that Gates was a consultant to the Ukrainian party when he introduced the advocacy group: ""Our assumption was that he was working for the Centre
column9: as we were hired to do."" (Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by Bill Trott and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Trott'
